title: No patient care, rude staff, careless GPs
body: Waited outside in the car park for about 1 hour to see GP but he didn’t came out. Receptionist informed him twice but no reply. Is this how you treat patients? CQC needs to see this. I will also write formal complaint. This is ridiculous

title: Good practice
body: I found them to be helpful & reassuring & they are good at getting in touch. I also get a print-out of graphs for my diabetic so I can control myself keep to my life style.

title: Flu jab
body: Well organised, no waiting, felt safe and friendly staff. It is how all medical practices would operate under the present trying conditions

title: Prompt, efficient care
body: I attended A&E with complications associated with a cat bite injury to my hand. There was ascending infection up my arm. I was seen by a nurse practitioner and then a plastic surgeon who admitted me immediately for intravenous antibiotics. I was then hospitalised in ward 60 for continued treatment overnight. I am very grateful for the prompt treatment that I received and hopefully I will continue to make a full recovery. All of the staff were lovely to me, very kind and caring, and also professional and knowledgeable. I would like to thank them all.

readBy.name: Hull University Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust

title: Miserable
body: A phone call from "someone" at the Surgery wanting a "medical review". Agreed. Phone appointment scheduled for 10.00 am 24/09/2020.  It's now 20.30 same day.  Nothing. A whole day wasted. Who exactly are these people?  Dreadful .. dreadful .. dreadful. Used to be back in the day a reliable surgery with whom one could feel confident. Unfortunately, no more.  So sorry to file such a bad report in these horrific times, but go somewhere else is my advice ..

title: The medical practice website is down!
body: I've been trying to access your website to in order to make an appointment to order a prescription and your website appears to be down! Therefore how am I supposed to be able to access you if you're unaccessible! This is pretty irresponsible!!

title: Great Doctors
body: It’s relatively easy to book appointments using the app. There are some great doctors and nurses there too, in particular the next generation of young doctors who read your medical Records fully before treating you. Very holistic . The only reason why I wouldn’t give this surgery five star is the quality of reception staff.

title: Shambolic system,lovely doctors and staff
body: I wanted to find out about my first ever flu jab. looked on the Surgery website for information...nothing.I rang the surgery and the message said I was 24th in the queue.I opted to be called back.I waited till 8 minutes before they closed and rang again. The recorded message confirmed the closing time in 8 minutes...and then told me it was shut! They never did call me back.My daughter rang the surgery yesterday about my 4 year old granddaughter....she was 38th in the queue. What on earth is going on that they can't even answer the calls in a timely manner? We can't blame Covid for everything

title: Great practice
body:
Answered my call straight away.
GP rang me back soon afterwards and asked me to report to the surgery as soon as possible. Having seen me, he sent me to A&E.  I am grateful for his swift response.

title: Excellent surgery.
body: Stanley Court Surgery is indeed one of the best. I have always appreciated their help and support. Genuine, caring and friendly staff, always professional and dedicated to providing the very best patient care.

title: Appalling Service
body: Turned up for appointment on time with card showing the time. The receptionist was immediately rude saying “What are you here for your appt is not until 1hr 20mins later.  Pointed out card was written by the receptionist. No apologies, just go outside in the rain and wait.  She was not very helpful.  The standard of service has deteriorated beyond belief at the Pinn.  This is the second time a situation  has occurred within three weeks. The previous time was a walk in. Was told to go outside and wait for a phone call. After 45 minutes of standing waiting outside, went back in and asked what was happening. Receptionist said you didn’t answer your phone. Showed her my phone there was no missed call.  Again told to go outside and wait. It is just not acceptable treatment of people who are ill. The reason why they are visiting the surgery is because they are ill.

title: Avoid - Main GP does not listen and is dismissive
body: We’ve  been with this GP for many years.   My family have had 3 issues and all have  gone on for weeks and months gradually getting worse with no resolution.   My concerns are minimised.  As a result, things get so bad that I’ve had to visit A&E twice, where the correct diagnosis and medication is given.

title: Worthing medical group excellent service and care
body:
I have been with the Shelly road surgery which is part of Worthing Medical group  for over 30 years . I am fortunate that despite being in my late 50s I am in very good health. I would like to comment on the excellent service I received on two recent occasions. One, a couple of years ago  required me to contact the surgery for severe ear pain , I was told that the Dr would call me back . I was called back within 15 minutes and immediately given an appointment within two hours.
 On another occasion I emailed the practice regarding a surgical procedure that the practice had diagnosed and then recommended me to a consultant. This consultant had then dragged the process out over almost two years failing to recognise that I was in pain and having real issues in my daily life and even with my job. I explained this in the email , and within an hour , I was contacted by the surgery who kindly explained that they would try and expedite the procedure.
 I have always had excellent service from the Drs and the reception staff , all of whom I know are really busy. I know i'm not allowed to mention anyone  but hopefully they will recognise who they are from this review , and my thanks for their efforts.

title: Poor service
body:
I have been ringing the surgery today as I have an infection on my both thumbs. I have been prescribed a flucloxacilin by a different surgery as I could not get through mine. I have a rash on my neck and terrible pain in both fingers so I wanted to contact my GP for the advice. The receptionist told me that someone will call me today and nobody did. I have been left with the infection. The receptionist are not very helpful and they don't know what they are doing. 
I had to register temporarily to a different surgery and they took me out form this one. After filling two forms they told me that they never received it even though I did it at the surgery so I couldn't get my appointment. After third phonecall they have told me that they had a problem to register me when I asked what kind, never received an answer. I am recently not happy with the service and the receptionist should go on some training. I am going to ring again tomorrow and I am wondering if someone finally going to see me.

title: Great midwife appointment
body: I've had my 32nd week midwife appointment on 24th September. My midwife is lovely, she really cares about me and my baby and answers all my questions. I need to say she is a great midwife. Thank you!

title: Terrible communication
body:
I had been referred by my optician to go to hospital for some tests and scans, as I am at high risk of going blind and may have tears in my retina. This referral had to go through Woodbridge, my GP. I was told i'd be contacted by letter to let me know if or when I had been accepted for tests. 




Having received nothing for a month and a half, I called Woodbridge only to find that 3 weeks ago they had a response from the hospital, saying they wouldn't see me for tests at the moment due to Covid and the fact that my optician did quite detailed scans already. However I wasn't informed of this at  all and neither was my optician. I was waiting at home to be told if I was going to have scans that would potentially determine if I was going to have severe sight loss and I wasn't notified at all.

Only a few weeks later I had a phone appointment, not at the scheduled time, where the doctor hadn't been shown photos that I'd been told to email in, and I'd been assured he'd be shown these. He then contacted me to re-send the photos using a special online service. What's going on??

Do the receptionists pass on information? If you have an important operation don't use this surgery, you'll never get your appointment unless you keep ringing up to ask.

title: Flu jab
body: Well organised speedy service. Dont know what would happen if it rained

title: Your online booing system needs some work
body:
When a patient  books a consultation through your online booking system, the practice should send a text or an email notifying patients what date and time their phone consultation will take place.  I already missed one appointment because I was in the shower, and I almost missed the call again today. Moreover i had to prepare some talking points for the consultation today, but the call took me by surprise so i didn't have time. As a result I might not receive the medical care I need, because i wasn't prepared.
When booking a normal doctor appointment, we book for a specific time and date, i don't understand why this is not the case here.

Another point is, I received a text asking me to book an online consultation with a gp, but gave no further instructions. None of the options on the website matched my enquiry, so i had to wait for 20 min on the phone just to ask which option to choose. Either the text or the online system should be clear about which option i should choose to book an appointment when none of the options match.

title: Excellent service
body:
I had to call the Dr's due to starting new chemo meds last week I had to call due to an ear infection.  The girls in reception were extremely helpful, putting me down for an advice call getting me a call back. I didn't have to go into detail all I had to say was a brief description none of what people say 'wanting to know your business'  gp phoned me back and I had antibiotics by the end of the day.  Also options I was given the details of how to book a telephone call online. For the future yes might not be the sameday but would be the day after an option to still know you are been attended too. 
Thank you again ladies a great bunch who is always there to help me and I know who have help my parents as well during lock down. 
 These girls have been there through out lock down helping each and every patient.  Well done again ladies

title: Good GP Service
body: I have been using this practice services for nearly the past 3 years. Unfortunately I had to use it quite often. In my opinion they are great. The staff is friendly but professional. Starting with reception finishing with GPs. I would highly recommend them.

title: Appointment System & Repeat Prescription Feedback
body:
I use Patient Access & the MyGP App. They are generally useful, but they have limitations. 

The surgery allows one problem per appointment, however, I cannot book a double appointment online - why this is? It is very frustrating. 

Perhaps IT could allow a limited number of double appointments per person. 

Also, I cannot book a GPN appointment for a cervical smear test online using either system, why is this?

author: Misterry
title: Alcohol Home detox
body: My story about alcohol start long time ago when I`m young, I start drink together to my colleges after secondary school. We going together some party and have fun and drink. Now I start DETOX to CGL never think will work but contrary help me a lot... Thanks to Stuart and John to support me and give me good advises. Now I start different life without alcohol. Help my family and relations with my partner and kids. BIG THANKS CGL.

author: Sholley
title: My mum
body:
My mum died on 22/09/20 at 5.15 am. The staff at Hairmyers Hospital Resus department and the staff in ward 3 were so compassionate and understanding and they were so helpful. My mum lingered for 18/19 hours and all the staff that we dealt with over this difficult time couldn’t do enough to help us and we greatly appreciate it. The staff on nightshift were so patient and gentle with our mum and with us. We felt they treated her as though she were their mum too and I just wanted to thank them for all their help. I’m not sure if you are able to pass this on to the staff/hospital but if you can we would really appreciate it. Wonderful staff at Hairmyers Hospital. Thank you all once again.  
x

readBy.name: South Lanarkshire Health and Social Care Forum

author: Mo1975
title: Hemaplegic migraine
body:
I was taken to university hospital hairmyers by ambulance last week as I go completely paralyzed down my right side with these migraines, which also mimics a stroke, it would normally correct itself but after several hours being stuck in terrible pain & paralysis, my family called an ambulance as they were worried it was a stroke.  
I was left in the waiting room for 3hrs with no way of communicating with anyone, unable to walk, get pain relief or go to the toilet. After over 3 hours I was taken to a cubicle with bright lights & noise that was overbearing for someone with chronic migraine, I started to slowly get some function back & called my partner to come & get me, still hadn't seen a doctor, it was degrading and extremely frightening, this is the second time I've been treated like this at hairmyers. I was left feeling as if I was a burden.  
I receive 39 injections of botox for chronic migraines, I am also high risk of stroke & we all know how urgent it is to treat someone having a stroke (FAST), there was nothing fast about treating me, I dont ask for special treatment, just that your staff are more aware of chronic migraine & how debilitating it is, simple things like putting the patient in a dark quiet room, its not that hard but would make such a difference, I hope I never need to be in hairmyers again, I was left feeling embarrassed, angry & it has put me off ever getting help again.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)
South Lanarkshire Health and Social Care Forum

author: SangCrash
title: Hysteroscopy ordeal
body:
I had a hysteroscopy to see why I had such heavy and painful periods. I was well looked after, however it wasn’t made clear to me that this might be as disturbing an experience as I found it! Two nurses were with me, talking away, to distract me, I suppose. One of them had to hold me down though as I tried to tell them through gritted teeth, ‘I.. can’t.. take.. this.. any… more..!’. I was in shock coming out of there. It was an extreme pressured feeling - a traumatic and barbaric experience for me. I couldn’t believe I hadn’t been sedated. I don’t remember being offered anything, or warned about this before I went in. I took a couple of pain killers as advised, and that was it. I could see on the nurses faces that they knew what I was in for, and another nurse did come out to see me in the waiting room and ask if I was ok. She looked concerned and I burst into tears. I was shaking with shock.  
I now live in Portugal, and on having my mirena check up, we got talking about my hysteroscopy experience. The gynocologist said that here in Portugal, women are always sedated for an hysteroscopy and suggested reasons why the NHS don't always do it. It has always bothered me that other women are going in for the same treatment and may have a similar or worse experience. I would like to see a change in the system so that everyone is sedated. There’s just no way of knowing if you can take the pain or not before you go in, in my experience, and it is not worth taking the risk.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)
Birmingham Women's and Children's NHS Foundation Trust

author: blackbirdej89
title: My Wife's appointment at ENT
body:
My wife attended the doctor at the beginning of the year regarding issues with her ears and a build up of wax. The GP said that they no longer perform procedures such as ear syringing at the surgery and that my wife would need to attend the ENT department at the hospital. We received an appointment for March this year but due to covid-19 this had to be cancelled and they couldn't tell us a time frame of when she would now be seen.  
We received an appointment finally for today, so i took my wife along to her appointment, ensuring to follow all the new covid guidelines of waiting in the car park etc. when we finally saw the nurse, my wife was informed that her procedure could not go ahead today as planned as the wax in her ears was too hard. The nurse said that she should have been using drops to soften this prior to attending the appointment today, but this had not been communicated to us prior to the appointment. Nor was it mentioned on the appointment letter. Had we known about it we would have applied drops. No prescription was given.  
This is upsetting as my wife has waited 13 months (since she first went to the doctors) to receive treatment for her wax build up. I am not happy that nothing was communicated to us prior to the appointment and because it is now having a knock on effect on other appointments my wife is required to attend with audiology to fit her hearing aid at the beginning of October. These appointments cant go ahead until the wax is gone. This is causing great distress because the nurse today told her that it could take up to 3 months to remove the wax and get another appointment. so she could be waiting months. We had been told at a previous appointment that the method for removing wax from ears could be done despite the wax being hard but that was not the case today. Poor communication and conflicting advice has led to upset and distress , along with the worry as to when she will be seen again.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: Sincere Thanks
title: Surgery to remove benign ovarian cyst
body: The team works! From GP to hospital staff, in particular pre-op nurses, anaesthetists, Gynaecologist, gynaecology nursing staff and auxiliaries, all excellent, so very professional and caring. Cannot express my gratitude enough. Sincere thanks.

author: katmar1950
title: My stay in hospital
body:
Sept 2020 3 day stay  
I would like to thank all the staff who cared for me during my recent stay  
surgeons anaesthetists doctors nurses I cannot praise you highly enough  
my care from you all was first class  
to the nurses in ward 209 who treated me kept me calm many thanks  
you were all fantastic  
all of you take care thanks

author: Ally-
title: Physio Telephone Assessment
body: Having injured my ankle, I was amazed that in current times I was able to have access to a physio within the week. I was so glad that I called the GP practice. I was wary of how helpful a telephone appointment would be but physiotherapist (Gail) was able to assess the injury, diagnose and come up with a really comprehensive treatment plan. I found her to be really knowledgeable and feel I have a much better understanding of the injury. I also had exercises emailed to me and a time frame in which to expect to achieve things. Really felt that the level of service delivered was much greater than my expectations and would recommend to anyone to access the service when they need it.

author: Mr not very happy
title: Upset and dissapointed
body:
Was seen by four different doctors in 8 hours .... Had blood. c t scan and urine samples covid test ...to be told but each doctor that there was something different everytime? ? ? ? I was on my own being told I need a op then told I dont? ? ?  
After this I was so scared about not knowing what was wrong with me, what the doctors was going to do nothing was clear not explained to me? ? ? I was that upset I had to leave and was told no? ? ? But I had to leave I was petrified

author: Stitcher
title: Credit where credit's due
body: In an era where people are quick to complain I think it’s important to give credit where credit’s due. At a recent procedure in FVRH’s endoscopy department I was most impressed with the care received. I was put at ease by every member of that department and alongside the nurses who actually carried out the procedure, (I don’t know their names), would like to say a special thank you to nurses Stella and Shona who went out of their way in their kindness towards me. Staff like this are worth their weight in gold!

author: Mand cost
title: Mental health services for parents
body:
Last year I was on the DBT group sessions weekly, which run on Tuesdays from 2-4pm. Being a single parent to two children I found it extremely difficult getting my children picked up from school so had could not attend a few sessions. Subsequently I was asked to leave group as the policy is if u miss 3 or more sessions you have to leave.  
I was slightly disheartened as felt the service was not being inclusive for parents who have to do school run. My psychiatrist then suggested I look at the recovery college and enrol on some classes there. Having looked through the time table the same problem has come up, with most of the classes between 2-4pm. I do not feel this is person centred- as surely there is other parents in the same situation as me, with limited childcare or support and living with mental health problems.  
I hope West London Mental health services can look into this, and try to accommodate everyone who wishes to use their services!

author: slappa tray
title: Mental health
body: I intended commit suicide 2018 and the ambulance was absolutely great, the physiatrist was good but only saw er for a year then ad no help until July 2020 and the crisis team was absolutely brilliant and really listened and supported me all time, helped me off my medication as was not helping making me worse, glad I've got there support

author: KelJ
title: Hydrotherapy
body:
I have a long term condition and I am in a flare up with severe pain, weakness and stiffness. I am unable to work or drive due to my condition and because of the flare up I am unable to do my daily exercises.  
Previously I was referred to hydrotherapy at the Inverclyde Royal and this really helped me manage my flare without relying on stronger medication. I have been advised that this pool is not currently open and that to access hydrotherapy in NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde I will need to travel from Greenock to either Paisley or Glasgow. This is very disappointing as the journey to access this service now will take around 3 hours per appointment there and back and is not one I can manage or afford.  
I am very disappointed that access to hydrotherapy is not offered equally to patients in Greenock and I would appreciate if the closure of this pool and the current demand for this service locally could be reviewed.

author: no names available
title: my recent stay in ward 17
body: I was admitted to ward 17 on sunday night and stayed for 2 nights. I cant fault the treatment I received in any way and ALL the staff were fantastic, you all do a fantastic job and I can never thank you all enough but Margaret one of the nurses who was on night shift on monday night (21st) you are a complete inspiration you told us a wee bit about yourself and you truly are an unbelievable woman. I hope this message finds it way to you...keep being you! ! !

author: Ecosse Princess
title: Uterine biopsy
body:
I had a uterine biopsy performed today at Hairmyres Hospital at Nurse Sheilas clinic.  
Prior to the appointment and procedure I was extremely anxious as prior to my appointment I had been to the Gynaecologist and she had tried to perform the biopsy in her office. I cannot thank the nurses enough for all their empathy, support and kindness that they showed me this afternoon! They truly are assets to the NHS! I couldn’t have gone through this process without all the support.

author: fredl
title: IRP - Roadmap to Recovery
body:
Once you have made the decision, honestly, that you need to overcome your addiction - in my case, to alcohol, you need to develop the skills and tools to get yourself out of the quagmire you have been stuck in, and prevent yourself falling back in again.
This is what the IRP did for me, it helped me build the ladder I needed to bring myself out of the dark depths I had fallen into.
When we are stuck in that quagmire, we descend into negative patterns of behaviour, can feel isolated, withdrawn and despondent - all of these areas need addressing, but there is no magic bullet, we need to learn to make small, sustainable improvements in all of these areas.
This requires a structured approach and methodology, and one which the IRP excels at providing.
By focussing on specific areas in each of the sessions, it helps you realise the importance of often simple things that we have, through our addiction, lost sight of. And this is a key to the success of IRP, reinforcement of things that we already know, but have chosen to ignore the significance of.
Another huge benefit of being structured in approach is that more time can be devoted to tackling specific issues one at a time, as the programme progresses, we develop the confidence to talk frankly and honestly about the problems we have had and/or are having.
We have to acknowledge, and become comfortable with the realisation that we are only ever one drink away from a lapse or a relapse. Identifying and managing the thoughts and feelings that could lead us towards that one drink is a fundamental building block of sustained recovery. IRP provides the techniques we have to master - it is then up to us to do just that.
I cannot praise the programme enough. At first I found it a little intimidating, but gradually, things started to sink in and I could see how this would work for me, and equally found that, after a while I was able to contribute back into the group, and that is a great feeling.
A big thanks from me to all at Inclusions for the incredible work you do.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: Dad's daughter
title: My dad’s admission to stroke ward
body: Jo, a Healthcare Support Worker answered my phone call from outside the front door of Aberdeen Royal Infirmary. My dad was in the stroke ward 5 hours post stroke and I was waiting outside the hospital for my mum to reach the ward to visit him after travelling for an hour to get there. She’d been with him when he had his stroke, but COVID-19 meant she couldn’t accompany him in the ambulance. She was anxious, upset and frightened. Jo said she would look out for Mum and take her back down to us after visiting him. She was reassuring and friendly and made me feel assured that both mum and dad were in safe hands. I work in the health service so feel comfortable in the environment but with my own relative being the patient I myself felt vulnerable. Thank you Jo.

author: likeablekt78
title: Great staff
body:
Great staff  
Warm and welcoming  
Great big ward bright and airy.  
a lot more room on this ward  
Patients are well spaced.  
Need more beds, chairs very uncomfortable. Especially if you have had long car journey, last thing you want is to be sat in another chair

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: topchef
title: Thanking the staff
body: I would like again to thank all the nurses and staff for their kindness and care during my stay on Ward 15 (Solihull Hospital), This is my second time this year and I know will not be my last. Living on my own get's very lonely, so coming into hospital isn't a trauma, it's a pleasure, having being cared for during my stay, I could even say if it wasn't for my dog Dylan I am sorry to leave. Thank you all once again and not forgetting the theatre staff

author: Innes
title: Visiting and communication with families during lockdown
body:
My elderly mother was admitted (as an emergency) to the Glasgow Royal Infirmary earlier this Summer. She was being treated for frailty and cognitive decline. In accordance with Lockdown Government policy she was denied a visitor.  
During her admission my mother who is deaf and registered partially sighted became agitated and delirious. Telephone calls on the ward phone became increasingly upsetting to the whole family as it became apparent that my mother was acutely distressed. She begged us to come to the hospital and take her home.  
After several fraught telephone conversations with both ward nursing and medical staff (on the issue of my mother’s capacity) it was decided that my mother would be allowed home as soon as possible in order to allow her to recover from her ordeal in a familiar environment with her family. I strongly feel that if my mother had been afforded the right to an essential visitor it would have been possible for her to remain an inpatient long enough to have the investigations that on a more recent hospital admission have revealed her diagnosis of dementia.  
Agitated and distressed patients with a CONFIRMED diagnosis of dementia have been afforded the right to an essential visitor during lockdown. Agitated and distressed patients who are SUSPECTED of having dementia should be afforded the same privilege. To do otherwise is surely inhumane.  
I have already contacted the Scottish Government on this issue. The reply I received from the Government made it quite clear that the hospital visiting policy be implemented using a flexible compassionate and person centred approach. In order to comply with the Government’s policy it would be necessary for senior management in the Royal Infirmary to advise managers at ward level to use their discretion and permit the flexibility that the Scottish Government told me it desires. I trust that this has happened?

author: elephantem89
title: Very good service
body:
Took unwell again. Phone and DoC doctor on call told me go to A&E. Was in there a couple of hours. Getting bloods. CT Scan. Very good service. Moved up into surgical two. Shannon and the team were fantastic who made me feel so relaxed. Couldn't have done anymore for you when I got discharged. I actually missed them. I've been in many a ward in different hospitals. I can honestly say surgical two was the best. Auxiliary staff. Perfect to such a good banter as well.  
Thanks Girls

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: TOO OLD FOR THIS
title: polyp removal and coil fitted
body:
I had one appointment before lockdown to investigate a post menopausal 2 week bleed, the lining of my uterus was measured to be slightly thicker than expected which prompted a further examination. The measuring was very uncomfortable and painful and I had stated I couldn't tolerate them going that far into my uterus without some form of anaesthetic.  
I was told a coil would have to be fitted which I said I did not want as I had had one removed earlier that year so we would have to discuss alternatives, I was told there were none. The country then went into lockdown and late into this, June, I was called to say they were doing some procedures. I went for a pre assessment to see if I was suitable, I was. The procedure was not explained, I mentioned I was not having a coil, I then had to isolate for 2 weeks, be tested for the covid virus 2 days before the date to go in to the victoria hospital, kirkcaldy in July.  
Nobody contacted me to discuss the procedure during the 2 weeks, I had been added to a consultants list whom I had never met or spoken to until the date, I had no idea what was going to take place, how long it would take or what to bring with me. I had been handed a letter that had no instructions and I wasn't contacted after the test, just had been told if I did not get a call the test would have been negative.  
I arrived at the hospital to be left waiting for over half an hour then shifted to the ENT ward, some problem with beds? My treatment after this was distressing. I was upset and anxious I had not been told it would be a general anaesthetic. I have a real fear after waking to them taking the long tube from my throat in my one and only other operation I have had in life. The anaesthetist seemed annoyed and unsympathetic and stated on the list of importance I was way down the scale, then proceeded with the fear factor that it was very unpleasant to have my procedure done under a local anaesthetic and I would really not like it. I felt coerced, I relented under duress to the general, Then comes to the matter of fitting of a coil, which the original doctor had put on my file I was having it fitted, then the other consultant had decided I was having too. I stated I would not, which should have ended the conversation which led them to continue to ask and under extreme stress, I had to agree. Again, I felt coerced. I know its a scary time with the virus, but the human factor was completely missing, I got no after care leaflet or any details on what to expect or what to look out for if something may be wrong, or who to contact, I left very upset and anxious to the way I was treated and emailed a complaint the next day.  
I got phone calls but did not feel anything had or could be done to make things right. The procedure should not have been done unless the same care and attention to detail to patient care, could be followed. I am left feeling upset and disappointed. I have since had the coil removed, which is another horror story for another day, it was like a form of torture to have it removed. This has made me unsure whether to ask for medical help if anything goes wrong in the future, I cant risk such bad treatment again.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students
Plymouth University Health and Human Sciences students, 2018

author: Missruss
title: Disappointed with Customer Service
body: Telephoned the surgery as head, ears and neck was in pain. Could just about focus. Explained this to the receptionist and was then told is sounds like an emergency but I would need to go online and book an appointment. Imagine, I could hardly focus and still I had to go online. I thought I may also need a blood pressure test, and again go online. In the end my son's dad bought a blood pressure machine, and I sought medical advise elsewhere. I have also noticed since some of the staff members have left the front desk the customer service level has dropped immensely. I think it is time I look elsewhere, as you could die before they use their discretion.

author: C2reOpinion
title: Awaiting a Manometry Test in Glasgow
body: I have been waiting for a Manometry Test for Achalasia for over one year now in Glasgow.   My surgeon wants the result of this test to know how best to operate or Treat me. I don’t know for sure. the reason for the delay. I am told it is a low priority procedure In doing any Manometry compared to e. g. cancer and that it might be due to delays in respect of Staff Safety due to Aerosol procedure being involved, but I just do not know whether it is worth complaining and if so to whom and on what basis.

author: NotesNightmare
title: Missing notes
body:
Our family moved from England to Scotland three years ago.  
Our new GP requested our medical notes from our previous surgeries, who confirm that they complied with the requests.  
Our GP practice has not yet received the notes.  
On trying to follow up, I was informed that only the medical practice can do this.  
When they tried, they were told that for GDPR reasons, as they are not us, and no information could be given to them.  
It is imperative that these notes be found and passed on to our GP.  
Who can help us to do this?

title: Hello is there anyone there
body:
Trying to get through to A&E it would be easier to fly to the moon in a wheelbarrow, Rang four times let it ring for 20 to 30 minutes each time no answer tried again got to speak to someone who transfer me to another part of A&E and when the phone was answered it was put straight down with not a word uttered and this happened on several more occasions.
As I have been trying for over an hour to get through and it’s almost 1 o’clock in the morning someone else is going to keep trying as I’m to angry at the moment to talk to anyone.

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

title: Innovative GP practice
body: Outstanding access to health care services such as online access, up to date website and amazingly even social media presence.

title: Annual health check nurse
body: Nurse very pleasant and professional during my visit for blood pressure check and blood sample for tests

title: A Leading Practice.
body: I was a patient who did not initially welcome the closure of Moorcroft Surgery having been a patient for 25 years, knowing my GPs and nurses really well.  I was extremely apprehensive and found the transition to the bigger medical centre rather disappointing.  After about 2 years I am so very impressed with all of the services offered and the individual medics that have treated me.  I have found the reception team welcoming, friendly and efficient.  The medical staff are extremely professional and ensure that they give you time as an individual.  The present Covid restrictions have been dealt extremely well  and all services appear to be maintained.  Personally, I am very receptive to GP phone and video consultations, finding them time saving and convenient.   I count myself very lucky to say that I am happy with my local NHS services.

title: Not good enough
body: My maternity care was transferred from Macc to SH. Although my care during my c-section was second to none, I can't say the same for the care on the ward. First I was sent home from my pre-op without medication so had to return. Then on the day of the section we waited from 7.30am-4pm for the operation with around 3-4hrs of no communication from staff to be told we were almost going home because it was late. My first night on the ward was good with some staff being very supportive and helping to change baby, support with  breastfeeding and respond to need for pain relief. However, one member of staff did put baby in bed with me along with my changing bag and said I would have to change baby myself because she was too busy. She never came back so I ended up co-sleeping, something I never wanted to do, especially on my first night as a first time mum. After one night I was feeling ready to go home and asked for the baby checks to be completed so we could be discharged. We asked different staff members all day to be told at 4pm that the staff who conducted the checks weren't around so I would have to stay another night. I could have gone home but would have had to return at 10am the next day and wait to be seen. I reluctantly stayed to multiple car journeys. My second night was unfortunately a busy night. I felt like I was left alone. Pain relief took ages to come, no support with a poor latch, no support with baby because I was mobile after having the catheter removed and limited response to the buzzers being pressed in my room for other women's first nights so lots of crying babies and unsupported new mums. A sad night to be a part of unfortunately. I completely understand that it was a busy few days and under the current pressure of covid19 maybe things are different. However, I do feel the level of care was below par and there could certainly be some improvements.

title: Very very good practice,
body: Nothing but praise for all that work at this surgary, they  have helped me to be able to breath very much better, they  are caring and understanding, in these trubbled times I praise them all for they all go above and beyond to help you and make you safe and better.

title: Great Practice
body: I have been registered with this practice for approx. 5 years now and have always received excellent care. When I compare the service to that received by friends and family it far exceeds what's provided elsewhere - even during the pandemic! During normal times it can be quite difficult to get an appointment but if it's urgent a doctor will call you back or you can see the duty doctor. If I submit an e-consult for myself or my children a doctor has called me within a hour! You can't get much better than that. The reception staff are very helpful too which seems to be unusual these days!

readBy.name: Dorset HealthCare University NHS Foundation Trust

title: Well looked after
body: I felt very safe during the experience. It was very well organised and the staff were extremely helpful. All precautions were in place and the whole experience was quick and efficient.

author: tucanamq79
title: Great ideas
body:
I had an excellent experience.  
Janet was a super expert in taking my blood sample. I didn't feel a thing.  
Having a dedicated cardiac, that is a great idea.  
Janet gave me direct contact numbers for a triage line which is also a great idea. Getting into the system is quite tricky.  
Having follow up checks/diagnosis makes a lot of sense. Proactive to prevent future reactions.  
The cardiac team are the best (Dr Magowan).  
Many thanks for all your help.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: Jenpf56
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Never experienced anxiety before
body:
Having never experienced anxiety before, I woke up one night feeling very anxious. I heard voices in my head telling me to kill myself. The voices were even telling me how to do it, specific methods, over and over. I phoned the NHS 111 service where I was told someone would contact me within 20 minutes. I phoned 4 times before I spoke to someone. I was unhappy with one of the responses who said they were due to go off shift shortly and was not able to help me. I hung up and phoned again.  
  
This time I was taken to the Northern General Hospital where I saw 2 women and they listened to me for a very long time. They were very good. A consultant came to see me as well and he gave me details about an app called ‘Feeling Good’ to listen to. There’s 12 different pieces to listen to. You listen to the first one for about 6 times, then the second one for 6 times and so on, and I got to say these helped me a lot. They calm you right down and I feel much better now, 90% better. I take my meds from my GP and meditate every day.  
  
A lady called Felicity from the Trust came to see me at home and gave me some leaflets. She also told me about the 4-5-6 breathing technique. I wish I could remember Felicity’s surname and where in the Trust she was from as I would really like to thank her. She also gave me some numbers to contact a helpline number and a number for SPA. I would use IAPT again.

readBy.name: Sheffield Health and Social Care NHS Foundation Trust

title: Flu jab
body: Very competent and efficient service well done everyone. I was contacted on a Sunday which I was very surprised at but I was in the surgery within 20 minutes of the call. I felt fine after my injection which is always a bonus and would definitely recommend the surgery and the service.

title: Great practice
body: Last year I have skin problem my legs very painful my Frist GP not help me then I was change Gp my GP good help me now feel very better

title: Uncooperative
body: I had a medical declaration form to be filled by Doctor. Its been six weeks and it is not done. I have called several times. The behavior of receptionist is uncooperative.

title: Brilliant service all round.
body: The flu jab program was excellent and very efficiently done by all staff. I felt safe with the whole experience.  Cannot fault any of it.  Brilliant service.

title: great docters/nurses
body: always returned calls doctors very good never let me down they work very hard in co vid times  and risk life in hard times

title: Friendly and knowledgable staff
body: I have found that since registering at Kingswood their staff to be nothing but professional, courteous and willing to help. Having relocated from a practice in London the change in attitude of the people working here is stark, nothing has been too much of an issue. I visited the practice a number of times both before and during the COVID pandemic and the measures that have been put in place to protect me as a patient are very positive to see. I would have absolutely no hesitation in recommending this practice and would note that even in these uncertain times, the practice and staff working there have been excellent in dealing with my health and issues requiring attention.

title: Brilliant practice
body: Excellent administration of our flu jabs. Organised a drive through at an airport. Very well managed and great way to ensure social distancing. The Blackmore Vale surgery has always been first rate whenever we have had a health query. Many thanks to them.

author: telescopiumsp59
title: Thank you for helping me
body: The health care I received was very helpful and very good. The doctor's and nurses are doing a great job. And I'd like to thank them very much for helping me tonight.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

title: professional and helpful
body: really good to see a doctors working through the issues that corona virus is causing. Even with the ever changing rules when I have needed an urgent appointment I have been able to get one in a reasonable time. It is clearly difficult but the staff have been very good at helping me. I have had phone calls from the secretary keeping me up to date with test results without having to chase. this helps put me at ease. thank you

title: Marvellous Team
body: I went into this clinic absolutely  terrified, the staff were so friendly and put me at ease and explained the full procedure to me and put my fears to rest. I was on my way home an hour after going in. I can't thank them enough and i won't hesitate when my other cateract needs doing, it is nothing to get worried about thank you very much.

title: Great practice
body: Well organised in the surgery. Social distancing observed.  Short duration in the waiting room as on time with the appointment for my wife and I to have the flu jab. As it was the first-time the nurse explained the contents of the injection and any side effects.  We were given a leaflet of who to contact if we had extreme side effects.

author: marchck87
title: Great
body: Great, S. T. A. R. S. always ENGAGED

title: Great hospital + Great Staff=Great experience
body: From the person who gave me directions in the Treatment Centre on arrival, the nurses on level 4, the anaesthetists, the surgeon and once again the nurses, it was a far better than I could ever have imagined. I felt immensely safe during Covid times and how everyone keeps smiling is credit to the great atmosphere on the wards and in the hospital as a whole. Prior to this date I visited the Lister for an ultrasound, followed by a biopsy and then the Covid Hub. In all these areas I was treated with dignity and kindness. I cannot thank you all enough for making, what could have been a highly distressing experience, into a relatively stress free time due to the amazing staff.

title: Professional Service. Helpful
body:
GP and reception staff are nice and helpful getting me these trying times 
Many Thanks 
Keep up the good work

author: ottew
title: Excellent Healthcare
body:
I had a fall in June and would like to thank Bromley Healthcare for the excellent service in received.  
Laura , Debbie and the nurses who visited were so good at helping me to get back on my feet and the confidence to be active again.

title: Great experience!
body: I attended A&E in September and I am so thankful to team of A&E and in particular my doctor who examined me. His professional and interpersonal skills were brilliant. Thank you very much for great service and attitude!!!

author: Vplus
title: Being a student and volunteer
body: I have been a student and volunteer at the Recovery college, for 3 year now. The Recovery College has been an essential part of my mental health recovery, during this time. I cannot emphasise enough how important my invovlement as a student, and particularly as a volunteer, has been for me. I have made some great friends through my involvement with the Recovery College. Again, this has played a major part in my mental health recovery, as we know how important connection with others is for us, in maintaining good mental health. I have always been listened to, and always felt that my opinions are valued, when giving them. I feel as though I am part of the Recovery College team, and I want to be part of the Recovery College, as long as they will have me. I would like to give my deepest, and most sincere thanks to Renée, and all who are involved with the Recovery College.

author: Gibmac
title: Child with broken arm
body: A few weeks ago my 7 year old broke his arm quite badly. We took him to the Emergency Department at Dr Gray's Hospital and the care that he received was outstanding. Even with all the Covid-19 measures he was seen quickly, calmly and efficiently by SCN Ian Darcy and then by Consultant Ali. They were very caring and kind to my wee boy, keeping him calm and distracted and they clearly explained the options to me as his parent. What could have been a very distressing manipulation was carried out with the minimum fuss and adequate analgesia and we avoided a return visit to theatre for sedation. We left the department reassured that we would be followed up appropriately and my wee boy was delighted with his cast in his favourite colour!

author: Titwf75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Visualisation for Relaxation
body: Great session. I felt really relaxed that I actually slept off. Thanks.

author: Master J
title: This team has never faulted
body:
I have been a patient in Day Medicine now for some time and I just want to highlight that this team has never faulted through this pandemic. They have never cancelled my treatment, continued to provide excellent levels of care and made a difficult time so much easier!  
They are my Covid Angels and can't thank them enough.

title: Excellent Prompt and Friendly Practice
body: I arrived early for my appointment and was seen almost straight away. The Nurse was brilliant. Showed humility and empathy as well as a caring nature. I then had bloods taken. Again, service was excellent and I didn't even feel the needle go in. I was walking out at the time of my original appointment.

author: Wishy pt
title: Lead by example
body:
I was very disappointed on entering the main entrance of Wishaw Hospital this lunchtime to see the volunteer who is there to support and advice the public on the wearing of masks and hand sanitising but was not doing this and had his own mask hooked under his chin.  
This is not professional.

author: shuddercx77
title: Pressure felt from the sessions
body:
I have been drinking for 30 yrs. Then started engaging with Stars.  
I felt pressures from the sessions. Feeling like I had to "keep up and progress" on S. T. A. R. S  
I felt it wasn't clear whether after the sessions, that the care would end.

author: elephantmz49
title: A great experience
body: I had a great experience at the sessions.

author: yellowhb39
title: Very good course leader
body:
I felt the experience very good  
The lady who took the class, was well spoken, obliging and caring, patience and understanding.

title: friendly and efficient
body: Always helpful and cheerful even with the current situation was in and out very quickly if I needed to see a doctor appointments are not to far bad

title: Terrible phone service and process
body: After following all online processes and phoning 111 we were referred back to talk to our doctor however we spent over an hour in a loop of calls with recorded messages telling us there was one person in front and finally continuous ringing. When dialled back in we were in the same loop with the same messages. Understand the challenges but at least get the process right you have had 6 months of practice utter shamblez

author: Rav4
title: My double prolapse and the lack of treatment
body:
I went to see the Gynaecologist at St Marys in august 2019 after being referred because I need surgery and am called a complex case. The gynaecologist said I needed surgery and they would put me on the list.  
In October/ November they phoned me to say they had looked at my notes and because I had had previous surgeries in the area they would need to open me up, could they have my permission if needed to go in through my vagina. I agreed, the doctor said they would amend the permission sheet.  
I heard nothing until July 2020 when I received a letter asking if I still needed surgery or had I had it elsewhere. I emailed and phoned to say surgery was now urgent as my prolapse is the size of a babies head. Since then I have heard nothing again.  
I went to my doctor 2 weeks ago who examined me and said they would write a strongly worded letter to my gynaecologist as it really is affecting my life and my marriage. I still have had no contact.  
I am at my wits end to be honest I feel disgusting having this huge thing hanging between my legs constantly. I have been on anti depressants for the past 5 months. I totally understand about COVID but I also know women have been having surgery and I feel like I have been totally forgotten about. To be honest I don’t know how much more I can take the pain I am in with it on a daily basis, infections it is getting worse

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: echokz95
title: My anxiety peaked
body:
Long before lockdown I was experiencing anxiety attacks. Just after the beginning of lockdown my anxiety peaked (coincidence or connected). I was at lowest since I was 13yrs old. I didn't know what to do or where to go. Then I met Tracy, Psychiatric Nurse at Westminster Hse.  
I believe Tracy went above and beyond her role as a nurse and made it her personal task to ensure my safety and wellbeing.  
I have been signposted or referred to various organisations to help me deal with the different aspects of my anxiety.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: hydrusgf38
title: Lovely journey
body:
Journey was good  
everyone very helpful  
ward easy to get to.  
Lovely surroundings  
Staff lovely.  
Bed good.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Manchester city
title: Having surgery, stents.
body:
This was my 1st time in hospital for surgery..so maybe you can understand my fears and thoughts,but the staff on T5 put my fears to bed.....they were all out standing,I cannot thank them enough,especially Hanna and Chelsea...a great big thank you.  
The operation went well and the surgeon were brilliant. Thank you all.

author: filingkd38
title: Biologic therapy
body:
I am a patient who is a day patient today receiving rituximab infusion. I have in the past been to hospital as a day patient and for appointments. I came in today very afraid of covid not my treatment, but the staff immediately reassured me, when I saw how strict social distancing was carried out. Staff wore masks, aprons, gloves etc, changed everytime they went to do something else. The ward was a four bedded ward, well spaced out. I felt safe. Staff as well as keeping us safe, were very helpful, cheerful and made me feel very relaxed. I feel social distancing should always happen, even in the future when we have hopefully got rid of Covid.  
Staff were lovely  
Many thanks.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: reticulumrj43
title: Attending the ward
body:
I have been attending the medical day care ward at the Lagan Valley Hospital every couple of weeks since April to get a magnesium infusion.  
The staff on the ward are great -very friendly and professional. Always make you feel at ease and comfortable - even during all the covid-19 regulations.  
Jill who is the sister on that ward is amazing - always makes sure she speaks to you and checks how you are even if she isn't dealing with your care. Never lets you leave without saying goodbye and making sure you know what the next stage of your treatment is - she manages a great team and deserves recognition.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: violetpm35
title: Happy Patient & Family
body:
My di who is 84 years was Pre-Assessed by Jackie the Senior Charge Nurse at the Victoria Hospital. He had been diagnosed with cancer and was due to have an operation. He has vascular dementia and the last time he had an operation it did not go smoothly which left my di and the family very distressed.  
Fortunately this time, my di was extremely lucky to be under the care of Jackie at Pre-Assessment. She fully assessed him and put plans into place which allowed me to be with him before and after his surgery. Jackie was compassionate, caring and kept the family informed. He went into hospital following his Pre-Assessment and had a successful operation and got discharged that night with no complications. My family and I cannot thank you enough for the time you spent putting plans into place to ensure that his journey was as smooth as possible.  
Further operations are required and we all feel very reassured for his next trip to hospital after such amazing care. Thank you so much, you will never understand the difference you made to my di's day in hospital. We are all extremely grateful.

author: sagittabk68
title: Complained about my loud music
body: I was up quite late one night and had some music playing on low. Someone knocked on my door; it was a member of staff. I answered the door: was told another patient had complained about my loud music. Then I stepped outside my room and locked the door. I put my ear to it and could not hear a peep. But they insisted. I am most unhappy at my treatment and underminement

author: augustwb56
title: Staff are excellent
body: I have been coming for treatment for over 6 years at CAH, the nurses and staff are excellent but there was always 3 or 4 patients in a small room getting treatment. It wasn't very practical, now I getting treatment with Biologic Therapy at South Tyrone Hospital. There's loads of space between each patient, the staff do everything to help make you feel comfortable during this pandemic. All the proper measures are in place, everything is spotless.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: polarisng63
title: Kind and welcoming
body: It was very welcome. I felt very safe. Nurses were very kind

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: leopardhc34
title: This is a great place
body:
I have attended Craigavon Hospital for treatment for nine years and have had the best of care.  
The day care centre has now moved to Dungannon Hospital as I have no complaints towards Craigavon I have to say the move has been easy.  
One because I have the same staff they know me and all the other patients.  
Also this is a great place the ward is bright and cheerful. We all feel safe and comfortable, would be happy to stay here although its a longer journey it has been worth it. It is hard for all staff working in the NHS but the staff that look after us in DCC are brilliant.  
I hope that during this crisis you all staf safe I cannot praise or thank you enough.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Gaz123
title: Outstanding care
body:
One day in September 2020 I dialled 999 because I couldn't breathe properly within 10 minutes the ambulance crew was here and they where absolutely outstanding couldn't fault them what so ever they done there usual checks at my home address and decided to take me to boston pilgrim hospital to get further checks.  
From my house all the way to the hospital they kept me calm and were very polite we even had a laugh and a joke when I arrived at the hospital. I was seen very quickly and efficiently they gave me the correct medication and took all appropriate precautions from the a&e department to the integrated assessment centre to the respiratory ward all staff where always there to help with any troubles I may of had. They kept me in longer then I expected but they where just going there jobs so I couldn't fault this very well done.  
To everyone at the pilgrim hospital in hospital for looking after me when I wasn't feeling myself I'm doing a lot better now and I have my breathing under control.

author: Twnetyfour
title: Feeling welcomed by all staff members
body: On arrival staff made me feel very much at home and welcome, the staff are always pleasant and friendly. I really enjoyed browsing around the shop and purchased a lovely top. The food has been very tasty and there is always lots of choice. My visitors have enjoyed coming to John Eastwood and found all staff members helpful and pleasant.

author: yellowym44
title: Very good service
body:
Brilliant very good service  
Better now.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: cyclonede59
title: Support arrived in no time at all
body:
Our strong, independent, fit as a fiddle 85 year old mother was given a very sudden diagnosis of advanced terminal cancer. We as a family were trying to digest this and the fact that she was deteriorating rapidly when she developed a chest infection.  
Our G.P. asked for support from the Acute Care at Home Team. In no time at all they arrived at mum's and immediately put her and ourselves at ease.  
Their professionalism, kindness and empathy were truly magnificent.  
Mum didn't have to leave the comfort of her own home and their support and reassurance at a very difficult time was invaluable.  
This service must always be available to those who need it.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: aprilkf78
title: Horizon Day centre
body:
Hi team  
These letters were received from our service users family.  
Thank you  
Rachael  
Medical Secretary  
--------------------  
To whom this may concern,  
I am writing this on behalf of my son. He has attended Highbury Day Centre throughout the Coronavirus Lockdown, and has received excellent attention. He has been picked up regularly each and every day, taken for long walks which he enjoys immensely - He comes home happy and contented and his behaviour has been first class.  
I can't speak highly enough of his staying at Horizon Day Centre  
Sincerely Yours

author: Emmrd63
title: I feel listened to
body: Today was the first time that my consultant listened to me. Every time I've asked to change my medication it has been refused. Today's meeting was a positive one and thats all down to you being involved. My consultant refused to look into my diagnosis or explain to me the side effects of my medication. Today you got me answers.
